awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Defining colonization mechanisms and functions of Streptomyces strains in root microbiomes
awd_abstract_narration:
The human population is projected to reach 9 billion people by the year 2050. To accommodate this increase in population, global food production will need to increase by 70-100%. Chemical fertilizers, such as phosphate rock, are commonly used to improve crop yields. However, many of these fertilizers are non-renewable resources that will continue to decrease in supply as the demand continually increases.  Alternatives to chemical fertilizers are, therefore, necessary to continue improving crop yields into the future. This need, combined with increased public awareness of host-associated microbial communities (microbiomes) and the benefits they provide to their hosts, has turned the attention of the agricultural biotechnology industry towards harnessing plant microbiomes by developing probiotics that increase plant growth and productivity. Before these plant probiotics can have widespread success as an alternative way to improve crop yields, it must be understood how microorganisms inhabit plant tissue consistently and robustly despite encountering various hurdles to colonization. In addition to plant-produced chemicals that can limit microorganism growth, other microorganisms competing for similar niche space can affect each other's growth directly via products such as antibiotics. This research will explore the mechanisms used by microorganisms to protect themselves against these harmful chemical attacks. Planned educational activities will provide education, resources, and training to local and regional communities, targeting underrepresented groups. Together, the intertwined research and educational plans will provide a new perspective to improve and complement product development by agricultural biotechnology companies to expand their potential success to enhance plant productivity.

Plants evolved in a microbial world, and, as with many other multicellular organisms, specific subsets of microorganisms assemble into stable host-associated microbiomes. Recent massive parallel sequencing studies using the universal 16S ribosomal RNA gene defined microbiomes for a wide variety of plant species. Results demonstrated clear overlap in internal root (endosphere) microbiome composition, even between the evolutionarily divergent monocots and dicots and across diverse soil reservoir microbial communities. These commonalities suggest that selective pressures, likely imposed by both the plant immune system and competing microbes, exist and limit successful colonization of the endosphere. This work will explore specific interactions between collections of Streptomyces isolates, non-Streptomyces isolates, and genetic mutants of Arabidopsis thaliana as a tractable model system. Streptomyces were chosen based on their ability to: colonize roots from a variety of plants, influence the viability of other soil microbes through production of secondary metabolites, and be controlled the plant immune system. This research will test the hypothesis that Streptomyces species act as keystone members of the endosphere through investigation of how chemicals produced by host plants and/or microbes shape root microbiome membership. The knowledge gained from these studies could facilitate consistent and robust plant colonization by beneficial microbes, even in the face of direct microbial competition and host defenses. Understanding these mechanisms will be critical as we move from basic lab experiments into development of plant biological products to increase crop yields, and thereby, global food security, as the human population continues to rise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plant microbiomes can help their hosts by protecting them during environmental stress, aiding in nutrient acquisition, and enhancing plant growth. In this project, we examined how plant microbiomes form from their complex surroundings. Soil is home to a multitude of different types of viruses, bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms. It is through this rich microbial community that plant root systems must grow and develop. However, research demonstrates that only a fraction of the microbes present in the soil live within root tissue. In this project, we focused on how a major plant stress regulator, salicylic acid, acts to shape the root microbiome. Beyond its important role in plants coordinating responses to stresses, such as high temperature and infection, salicylic acid is an industrial relevant antimicrobial compound present as the active ingredient in face washes and wart remover. Our work defined how salicylic acid contributes to microbiome formation by limiting growth of particular microbes present in soil, as well as by differentiating between strains of the bacterial genus Streptomyces.

            Streptomyces strains play important roles in environmental and medical settings. They are found in a wide variety of environments, including soil and roots. Streptomyces are also known to encode numerous specialized metabolites. Among these metabolites, are many well-known antibiotics. However, most of the antimicrobial compounds they produce remain uncharacterized. Because they are so prevalent in roots, we asked the question: Do Streptomyces influence the ability of other bacteria to colonize roots? Our specific focus was to untangle host-driven (i.e., salicylic acid) from microbe-driven (i.e., Streptomyces) influences on root microbiome assembly by using defined genotypes of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) and genome-sequenced Streptomyces.

To perform this research, we relied on available Arabidopsis genotypes with altered salicylic acid production and a large culture collection of genome-sequenced bacterial isolates. To explore how Streptomyces directly impact the other bacteria, we mixed them into what we call “Synthetic Communities” with dozens of members. We made different versions of these “Synthetic Communities” with and without Streptomyces present to examine how well the other bacteria colonize Arabidopsis with and without the ability to make salicylic acid. From these studies, we discovered that multiple mechanisms of selection were occurring in plants at the same time. We have evidence that Streptomyces limit particular strains from growing during colonization, but also during growth in liquid media when no plant is present. We also have evidence that Streptomyces trigger salicylic acid production by the plant after they colonize. This salicylic acid production by the plant then prevents other bacterial strains from becoming a member of the root microbiome.

This work has led my research lab in several new directions. We are now examining how beneficial microbiomes help their host by inhibiting opportunistic pathogens. Further, our exploration of other plant metabolites produced after colonization has allowed us to initiate new projects focusing on other important compounds, such as coumarins. Like salicylic acid, coumarins help plants to respond to stress like high pH or low iron but also can have antimicrobial activity. The definition of these plant-microbe mechanisms to allow synergistic growth of both are necessary to create better agro-industrial biological products that work more consistently and across a broader landscape.

Finally, this project resulted in beneficial broader impacts beyond the basic science conducted. Key broader impacts involved enhanced educational opportunities for students and the public. For example, the project developed a new K-12 module, which was provided to middle school teacher in a workshop in Tennessee. This module was also used to teach high school student directly in Michigan. The PI also participated in an MSU extension event for fruit tree growers to describe the differences between microbial pathogens that cause disease and beneficial microbes that prevent disease and help plants to grow. The PI has also interacted with the Michigan Soybean Committee to answer their questions about biological products that are being marketed to them, so they can become more informed consumers of these types of products. This project also provided technical training for numerous undergraduate and graduate students who will go on to contribute in various ways to society.
